An exploration of the possible interactions for Binary Decision-making processes.

Decision-making, physicality &
visual reduction

When Tinder was released in 2012 it introduced a new style of interface, establishing a novel way to tackle the discovery experience of its dating platform. The card-based swiping interface put in place a methodology for making discovery structured, efficient and seemingly more meaningful. The interface has three key components - binary decision-making (swipe left or right), physicality (the swipe itself), and visual reduction (the way the cards look).

This work is a response to Tinder and its interface, inviting you to explore how physicality and visual reduction affect the binary decision-making process. Eight unique interactions allow you to experience a variety of methods of engagement with binary decisions, providing an outlet for reflection upon how physicality affects the process. Consider, in comparison to interacting with abstract interface elements, how physicality allows for immersion in the experience.

Scroll down, browse and experiment with the interactions available. The card-based interface helps us to concentrate on the current decision at hand. Enable the messy deck type to become aware of the importance of this, as the cards become randomly scattered across the page.

Colophon

Binary has been built as part of an artistic investigation into binary decision-making, and the card-based interface. This work is a creative artefact, presented alongside a critical rationale for my BA (Hons) Digital Media Design dissertation at Bournemouth University. The codebase for the project is publicly available on Github.

This work was made possible thanks to the following projects:

  • headtrackr.js
  • guitar-tuner
  • tracking.js
  • webgazer.js
  • jQuery

Swipe

This interaction aims to provide context to the audience by closely replicating the Tinder swiping experience. This is achieved by replacing the mouse cursor functionality with direct control of the cards, so as a user moves their finger on the computer’s trackpad, this movement is emulated on-screen. Once the user passes the card past the left or right threshold, it will continue to be dismissed off-screen in that direction. Despite not having the visual finger-to-element connection that a touchscreen enables, this interaction does work to provide a simple application of Mine’s concept - removing the need to interact with abstract interface elements can increase the sense of immersion.
